title: Folkocracy
dek: The enchanting singer enlists ANOHNI, David Byrne, Brandi Carlile, and more for an interesting collection of covers ranging from traditional folk songs, to Neil Young tunes, to children’s lullabies.
seoDescription: The enchanting singer enlists ANOHNI, David Byrne, Brandi Carlile, and more for an interesting collection of covers ranging from traditional folk songs, to Neil Young tunes, to children’s lullabies.
promoDescription: The enchanting singer enlists ANOHNI, David Byrne, Brandi Carlile, and more for an interesting collection of covers ranging from traditional folk songs, to Neil Young tunes, to children’s lullabies.
socialDescription: Read Alfred Soto’s review of the album.

tout.title: The Stools: R U Saved?

title: R U Saved?
dek: The Detroit punk trio’s first proper full-length is a blast, but its abstract, evocative lyrics make it a welcome subversion of the punk formula.
seoDescription: The Detroit punk trio’s first proper full-length is a blast, but its abstract, evocative lyrics make it a welcome subversion of the punk formula.
promoDescription: The Detroit punk trio’s first proper full-length is a blast, but its abstract, evocative lyrics make it a welcome subversion of the punk formula.

title: But Here We Are
socialTitle: Foo Fighters: But Here We Are
dek: Dave Grohl gives himself over to arena-sized grief, reckoning, and resolve on the band’s most propulsive and purposeful music of the last two decades.

title: Lucky for You
dek: Alicia Bognanno’s snarling alt-rock and sledgehammer choruses are blunted by the muddy production on her fourth album.

title: Early Grave
dek: The Australian musician better known as Francis Inferno Orchestra trades his habitual house and disco for lo-fi indie that plays like a love letter to the eccentric records John Peel championed.

title: Horse Rotorvator
dek: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the UK duo’s second album, a groundbreaking avant-garde pop collage from the early years of the AIDS epidemic that grapples with the nature of death.
seoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the UK duo’s second album, a groundbreaking avant-garde pop collage from the early years of the AIDS epidemic that grapples with the nature of death.
promoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the UK duo’s second album, a groundbreaking avant-garde pop collage from the early years of the AIDS epidemic that grapples with the nature of death.

title: Bunny
dek: Beach Fossils’ latest album distills the best of their daydreamy indie-pop with new wisdom and existential angst. But they’re just still as laid-back as you remember.

title: The Sport of Love
socialTitle: Asma Maroof / Patrick Belaga / Tapiwa Svosve: The Sport of Love
dek: The three improvisers conceived their new album while soundtracking a film for Louis Vuitton, but the results, far from being glamorous or overblown, are intimate and conversational.
seoDescription: The three improvisers conceived their new album while soundtracking a film for Louis Vuitton, but the results, far from being glamorous or overblown, are intimate and conversational.

title: Détwat
dek: Twitchy, raunchy, and full of laugh-out-loud punchlines, the Detroit trio’s new album is the best ghettotech rager in recent memory.

title: Real B*tches Don’t Die!
socialTitle: Kari Faux: Real B*tches Don’t Die!

title: Freak Frequency
dek: The Chicago post-punk quartet’s jittery second album rails against gentrification, algorithmic overload, and the bankruptcy of life under an extractive system.
